close_symbols: Callback typedef used by OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry (if different from OS_FileIteratorClose)
explanation:
To decide whether pointers in OS_CloseAllFiles should be const-qualified you must know whether the iterator object (iter) and the entry callback argument are modified by the functions called.

- OS_object_iter_t (type definition): shows whether the iterator contains mutable state and which members would need const qualification if the iterator were only read. Without the concrete type you cannot assess whether passing a const pointer is feasible.
- OS_ObjectIdIterateActive (prototype/definition): this initializes the iterator via &iter. If it modifies the iterator state (likely) then the parameter cannot be const; the prototype/definition will show whether the parameter is declared const or not and whether it writes to iter.
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext (prototype/definition): called as OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter) in the loop condition. If this function advances/modifies the iterator, the parameter must be non-const. The prototype/definition reveals const qualification and modification semantics.
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry (prototype/definition): called with &iter and a callback. You must know whether this function mutates the iterator (and whether it takes the iterator pointer as const) and the exact type/signature of the callback parameter to determine if that pointer (or any pointer passed to the callback) could be const.
- OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy (prototype/definition): destroys or cancels the iterator via &iter. If it modifies/cleans up iterator state, it should take a non-const pointer; the prototype/definition is required to confirm this.
- OS_FileIteratorClose (prototype/definition): the callback passed into ProcessEntry — you need its parameter types and whether it modifies any object pointed to (for example a token or object record). This determines whether pointers passed into the callback could or should be const-qualified.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE (macro/enum): the type/value passed to OS_ObjectIdIterateActive may influence which iterator implementation is used and thus whether the iterator functions mutate state; also some APIs vary behavior by object type.
- Callback typedef used by OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry (if different from OS_FileIteratorClose): the formal typedef/signature that ProcessEntry expects (e.g. pointer-to-function type) is needed to verify const qualification in the function-pointer parameter and whether ProcessEntry promises not to modify the object passed to the callback.

Collecting these prototypes/typedefs/definitions lets an analyst determine where pointer parameters are read-only versus modified and thus whether const qualification is applicable and compliant with MISRA guidance.
